video.title: ASP.NET Core MVC Course (.NET 5)
video.description:
Learn ASP.NET Core 5 MVC(.NET 5) in this complete tutorial course for beginners. 

After learning about the history and basics of ASP.NET Core, you will learn how to build a small book list application with CRUD operations. You will learn how to use the Entity Framework for integration with a database with ASP.NET Core Razor Pages.

You will build a CRUD application with validations and finally deploy the application on Azure! 

💻 Code: https://github.com/dotnetmastery/Rocky

✏️ Course from Bhrugen Patel. Check out more of his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC-4lngmBF7h1OVzmCuDiNdw

🔗 Watch more courses from Bhrugen at his website: https://www.dotnetmastery.com

It could be helpful to have some familiarity with C# and SQL. If you want to learn about those topics, try these videos:
🎥 C#: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GhQdlIFylQ8
🎥 SQL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HXV3zeQKqGY

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
Section 1: Introduction
⌨️ (0:00:00) Welcome
⌨️ (0:03:52) Tools
⌨️ (0:05:59) ASP.NET Core
⌨️ (0:10:15) Create Project
⌨️ (0:14:11) Project File
⌨️ (0:15:54) Program Class File
⌨️ (0:17:21) Dependency Injection
⌨️ (0:21:55) StartUp Part 1
⌨️ (0:24:21) StartUp Part 2
⌨️ (0:27:46) Routing in MVC
⌨️ (0:33:47) AppSettings
⌨️ (0:34:37) wwwRoot and launchSettings
⌨️ (0:37:28) MVC Application
⌨️ (0:41:13) Routing in Action
⌨️ (0:45:02) Views in Default Project

Section 2: Database Setup & Category CRUD
⌨️ (0:49:55) Create First Model
⌨️ (0:53:30) Add Connection String
⌨️ (0:56:59) Setup DbContext
⌨️ (1:02:23) Complete DbContext Configuration
⌨️ (1:06:12) Push Category to Database
⌨️ (1:09:47) Check Database
⌨️ (1:11:00) Add Category Controller
⌨️ (1:13:52) Add Category Index View
⌨️ (1:16:24) Get all Category
⌨️ (1:20:59) Display All Category
⌨️ (1:26:19) Add Category Part 1
⌨️ (1:31:16) Add Category Part 2
⌨️ (1:36:46) Add Category Part 3
⌨️ (1:40:43) Assignment
⌨️ (1:41:53) Solution

Section 3: Validations and Forms
⌨️ (1:48:14) Validations in ASP.NET Core
⌨️ (1:52:52) Client side and server side validations
⌨️ (1:57:13) Passing Parameters on Redirect
⌨️ (2:00:27) Category Edit Get Action
⌨️ (2:04:16) Update Category
⌨️ (2:06:31) Delete Category
⌨️ (2:10:28) Font Awesome
⌨️ (2:15:04) Assignment
⌨️ (2:15:41) Assignment Solution
⌨️ (2:20:46) Azure Deployment

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Adam Comerford
topLevelComment.text:
In the DeletePost(int? id) method, the 'id' parameter would always be set to null for me. Anyone have any idea why?
My 'Delete.cshtml' is identical to his, but it seems it doesn't pass along an 'id' to the Post method. I switched the parameter to a Category object and it worked fine.

replies.author: Henry Hayes
replies.text: @Adam Comerford Cannot tell you how grateful I am that I found this comment :D

replies.author: Adam Comerford
replies.text:
Figured it out - parameters of the Action method must be the same name as the field of the model returned to the method.
I named Category's id 'CategoryId', so the parameter 'id' didn't match the field of the model. It is also case-insensitive.

replies.author: Kaustav Dutta
replies.text:
Click on web application when you're selecting the templates during new project creation. There it will give you a few options on what kind of webapp (api, mvc etc.). Select MVC there.

After that choose the target framework. The latest is .NET 5.0 but .net core 3.1 has LTS. Choose which one you want and that should give you the template in this video.

topLevelComment.author: Branica
topLevelComment.text: Excellent tutorial. Keep going! A nice touch with the Azure implementation. As a developer who is transitioning from Web Forms to MVC, this is the best tutorial I've seen so far. What I noticed in all the tutorials: no example on how to relate two models. It would have been great if you had added another separate video and explained how to link the Category and Application Type models to each other, just as an example, because it's a very common need for beginners. Even so, I would still rate this tutorial 10/10. Thanks!

topLevelComment.author: clamum
topLevelComment.text:
Great video, thanks man!

One question about Validation, particularly server-side vs client-side: should you always put in server-side validation (i.e. the check for "ModelState.IsValid")? It's my understanding that if you leave that server-side validation off, and just rely on client-side validation, if someone had JavaScript turned off they could bypass your validation. Is that true?

replies.author: Tim S.
replies.text: Never ever turn off server-side validation. Client-side is just a trick to make server load lower.

topLevelComment.author: AskaniIT - Learn in minutes
topLevelComment.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XX8ziH7PY3g
Please click on the above link to watch the video that describes ✅ what is Dependency? ✅ What is Dependency injection & how it helps to avoid dependency between classes? 
And also covers
✅An example program without using Dependency injection.
✅Dependency injection in Asp.Net core, .Net 5, .net core.
✅Fixing example problem with Dependency Injection in .Net 5.
✅Various Dependency Injection Technics.
✅Service Life Time.

topLevelComment.author: Ali Baig
topLevelComment.text: Hi, I am using Visual Studio for MAC and i can't find the nuget console in it so how I run my migrations?

replies.author: Johann Sebastian Bach
replies.text:
google dotnet ef migrations command and it's usage.
I am also coding on a mac, and I can add migrations and update my db using the terminal window in VS mac in the relevant project's directory (dotnet command needs to find your .csproj file for it to work). You might need to download some packages for dotnet command to work but everything is pretty straight forward when you google it online. Hope it works out!

topLevelComment.author: Michael Ganzer
topLevelComment.text: This video should have come with a warning label attached: Not intended to help you become a good developer. It's full of anti-patterns, neglects clean code and replaces qualified explanations with "just let the thing do its magic". The easy access to such videos is one of the main reasons for the glut of sophomoric wannabe- and copycat-coders, unable to work in a team, unable to write understandable or at least maintainable code. All show and no substance!

replies.author: Andrey Kurochkin
replies.text: So that label or disclaimer is really needed. Like tutorial is only intended to get you more familiar with ASP.NET Core, and not intended to show you best practices of patterns and so on. To let everyone know that the production code they produce got to be less straightforward. In any case, that tutorial is appropriate as an introduction to ASP.NET Core

replies.author: Johann Sebastian Bach
replies.text:
As a sophomore studying cs I agree with you completely Michael! Most of the instructive videos I have found online just expect the viewers to watch along and copy code. We want to find resources that would teach us how to code and how to think, not resources that would only make us transcribe stuff.
I'd love if you could recommend me better resources cause I need to learn .net. Should I just stick with the documentation?

replies.author: Shayan
replies.text: To see the changes while the app is running on the UI. For example you add h1 tag in your cshtml file while your code is running then by having the Razor run time you dont need to restart the entire application. You just refresh the page.

Thanks for the video!

So there's no difference between .NET Core 3.x and .NET 5?

replies.author: Obinna Okafor
replies.text: Better performance and more apis have been added to .NET 5. So, .NET 5 is a superset of .NET Core 3

replies.author: niclo
replies.text:
Most APIs should be quite stable at this point so probably you are not going to see many changes indeed. 
Also considering the new .NET roadmap with a new major version every year it's going to be something like Angular where you hardly can point out differences between two given versions
